Award.AwardTitle: ADVANCE Adaptation: Gender Equity Advances Retention in STEM at Wayne State University (WSU GEARS)

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wayne State University (WSU) is an urban campus in the heart of Detroit, Michigan. WSU GEARS ADVANCE project focuses on systemic institutional and cultural change to move WSU toward a place of belonging and valuing diversity where women STEM faculty thrive and succeed. In 2010, women comprised under 14% of STEM faculty. WSU began to address this gender imbalance through increased oversight of regular search procedures and by workshops that stressed the value of diversity and the risks of implicit bias. The result was a steady increase of women in WSU’s STEM faculty to 20% in 2018; notably less than 3% of these women were underrepresented minorities. While WSU has continued to increase these numbers and strengthen pathways for success of women and underrepresented minorities, addressing structural challenges at all institutional levels remains a priority. WSU GEARS will leverage successful intervention strategies developed by WSU and NSF ADVANCE peer institutions. This project will reshape the campus inclusion culture by capitalizing on existing momentum and collaborations, adapting relevant policies and practices at departmental, college, and university levels.

The WSU GEARS ADVANCE Adaptation Project will reduce inequities for women and underrepresented minorities in STEM faculty through systemic change. Specifically, this project will tackle three barriers to the hiring, promotion, and retention of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM on the WSU campus: (1) toxic work environments, (2) work/family/life strains, and (3) unequal workload burdens. To overcome these barriers, WSU GEARS will adapt proven programs developed under prior ADVANCE programs through the following integrated tracks: nuanced data collection to inform policies and practices (Wayne Drives), enhancement of existing WSU programs (Wayne Shifts), and creation of new WSU programs (Wayne Accelerates). The WSU GEARS Project will: 1) promote successful programs that improve campus climate and create greater equity among STEM faculty in hiring and retention; 2) identify additional barriers for women and underrepresented minorities in STEM, especially for intersecting identities, that need to be tackled beyond the current programs; and 3) provide nuanced data to guide institutional improvements for women and underrepresented minorities. WSU is committed to sustaining outcomes beyond the award term and will invest in institutionalizing successful programs to continue to enact positive systemic change.

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions. Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate. ADVANCE “Adaptation” awards provide support for the adaptation and adoption of evidence-based strategies to academic, non-profit institution of higher education as well as non-academic, non-profit organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Wayne State University Gender Equity Advances Retention in STEM (WSU-GEARS) project implemented evidence-based programs to improve equity for women and underrepresented minority faculty, with an emphasis on STEM disciplines. Through the integrated tracks of data collection (Wayne Drives), enhancement of existing WSU programs (Wayne Shifts), and the creation of new WSU programs (Wayne Accelerates), the project sought to reduce inequities by addressing three barriers to hiring, retention, and advancement: (1) hidden and unequal workload burdens, (2) work/family/life strains, and (3) toxic work environments. Using a multifaceted data collection effort led to the creation of the following programs:

To promote equitable workloads, we launched the Workload Equity Pilot Project to collect and analyze faculty workload data. Based on the analysis, we shared a set of best practices with participating academic units. We also conducted workshops to bring awareness on the complex innerworkings of faculty workloads, for both leadership and faculty. We offered support to help departments begin their own, tailored conversations about ways to address the various types of hidden and unequal workload within their unit. Through these efforts we learned that many academic units have begun conversations about workload, reviewing their practices, and developing new policies and procedures toward creating more effective and equitable ways of distributing the many ways faculty contribute to their unit and beyond.

To support work/family/life, the WSU-GEARS team created the Family Advocacy Network (FANs). The FANs manual and at-a-glance policy guide are a comprehensive resource guide for information on care-related resources, parental and other types of leave, and wellness. We trained faculty to be family advisors who offer peer-to-peer, confidential support to assist faculty in navigating the complexities of work/family/life. FANs also included the job candidate program to further support a family-friendly and inclusive campus during the hiring process. Academic units shared written resources with candidates prior to their campus visits and during their time, they met with a FANs faculty advisor. This offered candidates a confidential space for prospective colleagues to ask questions related to work/family/life at WSU. The response to this new aspect of the hiring process was very favorable, with chairs indicating it helped recruitment efforts. Likewise, new faculty recruited thought the program was unique to WSU, provided useful information to assess the university, and factored into their decision to accept the job offer.

To build healthy work environments, we implemented the Bystander Leadership Workshop. The goal is to provide faculty with the opportunity to learn and practice effective techniques to interrupt instances of implicit bias and discrimination. Participants said the role play scenarios and the opportunities to practice bystander techniques were the most effective aspects of the workshop.

Cutting across the three barriers, the team developed mid-career support with the Associate to Full Workshop series that addressed demystifying the promotion process, assessing the next steps, engaging with leadership, crafting the narrative, and creating a strategic plan. We have developed a toolkit that incudes strategies and best practices for mid-career faculty.

Finally, we have secured ongoing support for the sustainability of the WSU-GEARS ADVANCE efforts beyond the scope of the grant. This includes the institutionalization of: (1) support for continued promotion of workload equity, including our workshops and development of the best practices toolkit; (2) the work/family/life support through the FANs program, including the faculty advisors and expansion of job candidate program across campus; (3) the Bystander Leadership Workshop, in coordination with the Office for Inclusive Excellence; and (4) the mid-career faculty professional development with the Associate to Full workshop, in coordination with the Office of Faculty Development and Faculty Success. To support these efforts, positions for a director of faculty equity initiatives was created, along with a coordinator who will assist with the equity initiatives and serve as the Family Services Coordinator.
